facts.text: The case is Writ Petition No. 2371 of 1974 in Original Appellate Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 2371 of 1974.  Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution.  K. Jain, for the

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BHAGWATI, J.

anchor.surface_text: S. Chatterjee, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI, J. This petition is directed against

facts.text: Petition directed against order of detention dated 30th March 1973 made by District Magistrate Nadia under section 3(1) of MISA 1971

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI, J. This petition is directed against an order of detention dated 30th March, 1973 made by the District Magistrate, Nadia under section 3 2  1  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

facts.text: Order of detention recited satisfaction of District Magistrate to detain petitioner to prevent acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention recited the satisfaction of the District Magistrate that with a view to preventing the petitioner from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order it was necessary to detain him and directed that the petitioner be accordingly detained.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 3rd April 1973 pursuant to detention order

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention, the petitioner was arrested on 3rd April, 1973 and at the time of his arrest the grounds of detention dated 30th March, 1973 were served upon him together with their translation in Bengalee language.

facts.text: Grounds of detention dated 30th March 1973 served on petitioner at time of arrest with Bengalee translation

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention, the petitioner was arrested on 3rd April, 1973 and at the time of his arrest the grounds of detention dated 30th March, 1973 were served upon him together with their translation in Bengalee language. The grounds of detention started with a recital that the petitioner was being detained on the ground that he had been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order and set out one incident of dacoity companysitted by him on the basis of which the District Magistrate had reached his subjective satisfaction in regard to the necessity of detaining the petitioner.

facts.text: Grounds of detention stated petitioner acting in manner prejudicial to public order based on one incident of dacoity committed by him

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention started with a recital that the petitioner was being detained on the ground that he had been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order and set out one incident of dacoity companysitted by him on the basis of which the District Magistrate had reached his subjective satisfaction in regard to the necessity of detaining the petitioner. The usual ritual prescribed by the Act was thereafter followed and the order of detention was approved, by the State Government, the representation of the petitioner was companysidered and rejected, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board and on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, the order of detention was companyfirmed by the State Government.

facts.text: Incident in grounds was dacoity in third class compartment of running train where cash money stolen

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be numberdoubt that if the order of detention was based on the subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely. to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, it would be bad because the incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train set out in the grounds of detention would be wholly irrelevant to support such subjective satisfaction. It would be impossible for any rational human being to say that an incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train where cash money was stolen is such an act that from it an inference can be raised that the person companymitting the dacoity would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services ,essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: Order of detention approved by State Government

anchor.surface_text: The usual ritual prescribed by the Act was thereafter followed and the order of detention was approved, by the State Government, the representation of the petitioner was companysidered and rejected, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board and on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, the order of detention was companyfirmed by the State Government.

facts.text: Petitioner's representation considered and rejected

anchor.surface_text: The usual ritual prescribed by the Act was thereafter followed and the order of detention was approved, by the State Government, the representation of the petitioner was companysidered and rejected, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board and on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, the order of detention was companyfirmed by the State Government. The present petition was filed by the petitioner from jail challenging the validity of this detention.

facts.text: Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board and order confirmed by State Government on receipt of Board's opinion

anchor.surface_text: The usual ritual prescribed by the Act was thereafter followed and the order of detention was approved, by the State Government, the representation of the petitioner was companysidered and rejected, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board and on receipt of the opinion of the Advisory Board, the order of detention was companyfirmed by the State Government. The present petition was filed by the petitioner from jail challenging the validity of this detention. There were several grounds urged before us on behalf of the petitioner in support of the petition, but it is number necessary to refer to all of them since there is one ground which is, in our opinion, sufficient to invalidate the order of detention.

facts.text: Present petition filed by petitioner from jail challenging validity of detention

anchor.surface_text: The present petition was filed by the petitioner from jail challenging the validity of this detention. There were several grounds urged before us on behalf of the petitioner in support of the petition, but it is number necessary to refer to all of them since there is one ground which is, in our opinion, sufficient to invalidate the order of detention. That ground rests on an averment made by the District Magistrate in paragraph 4 of the affidavit filed by him in reply to the petition.

facts.text: District Magistrate filed affidavit in reply to petition stating in para 4 bona fide satisfaction for public order and also that if not detained likely prejudicial to supplies and services

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate stated as follows in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-reply I say that I passed the said order of detention after being bonafide satisfied from the materials on record as stated in the grounds of detention and so surrounding circumstances that with a view to preventing the detenu from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of Public Order it was necessary to detain him under the provisions of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971-I further state that having regard to the nature of the act and the manner in which it was companysitted by the detenu  as disclosed in the rounds furnished to the detenu  and effect thereof on the public order I was bonafide satisfied that the said act was sufficient for making the said detention order. I was also further satisfied that if the detenu petitioner is number detained under the said Act he is likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: Petitioner argued no nexus between grounds of detention and DM's satisfaction regarding supplies and services

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from this statement made by the District Magistrate that from the material on record he was number only satisfied that-was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, but was also satisfied that if the petitioner was number detained, he would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity. The argument of the petitioner was that there was numbernexus at all between the grounds of detention companymunicated to the petitioner and the subjective satisfaction of the District Magistrate that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity and the order of detention based inter alia on such subjective satisfaction was invalid.

facts.text: Respondent contended that averment in para 4 about supplies and services crept in by mistake and should not be considered

anchor.surface_text: The respondent realising the seriousness of this difficulty in its way, companytended that the averment in paragraph 4 of the affidavit-in-reply that the District Magistrate was satisfied that if the petitioner was number detained, he would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity had crept in through mistake and it should-not be taken into account by the Court in adjudging the validity of the order of detention. The argument of the respondent was that the only subjective satisfaction on which the order of detention was founded was that it was,necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as re- cited in the order of detention and the grounds of detention and it was number companyrect to state that the District Magistrate was also subjectively satisfied that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity and had on that account made the order of detention.

facts.text: Court rejected respondent's contention that para 4 averment was a mistake as no correcting affidavit filed by DM

anchor.surface_text: We do number think we can accept this companytention of the respondent. It must be remembered that the affidavit-in-reply has been made by the District Magistrate himself and we must presume that the District Magistrate must have made the statements companytained in the affidavit-in- reply with the sense of responsibility which his high office necessarily carries. If the District Magistrate was also number subjectively satisfied in regard to the likelihood of the petitioner to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, he would number have made such an averment in paragraph of his affidavit-in-reply. Ordinarily when an averment is made by a high officer like the District Ma- gistrate in an affidavit which is made on oath, the Court is inclined to accept the averment as companyrect and the burden lies heavy on the party who alleges to the companytrary.

facts.text: Court accepted para 4 averment of DM as correct and held order based on satisfaction re public order and supplies/services

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, accept the averment made by the District Magis- 7 L 319 Sup CIJ75 trate in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-ireply as companyrect and proceed on the basis that the order of detention was based number only on his subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order but also on his further subjective satisfaction that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

facts.text: Court held solitary ground of dacoity in train compartment for theft of money irrelevant to subjective satisfaction re supplies/services

anchor.surface_text: And if that be so, the order of detention must be held to be invalid since the incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train for companymitting theft of money which companystituted the solitary ground of detention was wholly irrelevant and the subjective satisfaction of the District Magistrate that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity companyld number be founded upon it and was hence-colourable and numbersatisfaction at all.

facts.text: Court allowed the petition made rule absolute and directed petitioner set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

facts.text: K. Jain appeared for petitioner S. Chatterjee for respondent

facts.text: Several grounds urged by petitioner but court considered one sufficient to invalidate detention

anchor.surface_text: There were several grounds urged before us on behalf of the petitioner in support of the petition, but it is number necessary to refer to all of them since there is one ground which is, in our opinion, sufficient to invalidate the order of detention. That ground rests on an averment made by the District Magistrate in paragraph 4 of the affidavit filed by him in reply to the petition.

arguments.claim: Passed detention order after bona fide satisfaction from materials in grounds and circumstances that necessary to detain to prevent acting prejudicial to public order; also further satisfied that if not detained likely to act prejudicial to supplies/services

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate stated as follows in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-reply I say that I passed the said order of detention after being bonafide satisfied from the materials on record as stated in the grounds of detention and so surrounding circumstances that with a view to preventing the detenu from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of Public Order

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nce can be raised that the person companymitting the dacoity would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and service

arguments.court_reasoning: Averment accepted as correct due to presumption for public officer's affidavit absent correction

arguments.claim: Order of detention based not only on subjective satisfaction re public order but also on further subjective satisfaction re preventing prejudice to supplies/services; solitary ground of dacoity wholly irrelevant to latter making such satisfaction colourable and no satisfaction at all hence order invalid

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, accept the averment made by the District Magis- 7 L 319 Sup CIJ75 trate in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-ireply as companyrect and proceed on the basis that the order of detention was based number only on his subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

holdings.text: We do not think we can accept this contention of the respondent that the averment in paragraph 4 of the affidavit-in-reply had crept in through mistake and it should not be taken into account; the affidavit-in-reply has been made by the District Magistrate himself and we must presume that the District Magistrate must have made the statements contained in the affidavit-in-reply with the sense of responsibility which his high office necessarily carries; ordinarily when an averment is made by a high officer like the District Magistrate in an affidavit which is made on oath, the Court is inclined to accept the averment as correct and the burden lies heavy on the party who alleges to the contrary; we cannot therefore lightly accept the submission of the respondent that the District Magistrate has made an incorrect statement in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-reply; the position might have been different if the District Magistrate himself had made a subsequent affidavit stating on oath that he had made a mistake in the earlier affidavit-in-reply and explained the circumstances under which he came to make such mistake but here there is no affidavit made by the District Magistrate confessing his mistake.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think we can accept this companytention of the respondent. It must be remembered that the affidavit-in-reply has been made by the District Magistrate himself and we must presume that the District Magistrate must have made the statements companytained in the affidavit-in- reply with the sense of responsibility which his high office necessarily carries. If the District Magistrate was also number subjectively satisfied in regard to the likelihood of the petitioner to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, he would number have made such an averment in paragraph of his affidavit-in-reply. Ordinarily when an averment is made by a high officer like the District Ma- gistrate in an affidavit which is made on oath, the Court is inclined to accept the averment as companyrect and the burden lies heavy on the party who alleges to the companytrary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit statements by high public officer like District Magistrate presumed correct due to office responsibility; heavy burden to disprove; mistake claim requires subsequent correcting affidavit confessing and explaining error, which was absent.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, accept the averment made by the District Magistrate in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-reply as correct and proceed on the basis that the order of detention was based not only on his subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order but also on his further subjective satisfaction that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, accept the averment made by the District Magis- 7 L 319 Sup CIJ75 trate in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-ireply as companyrect and proceed on the basis that the order of detention was based number only on his subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order but also on his further subjective satisfaction that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted DM's affidavit averment as correct per presumption for public officer's oath statements; order founded on dual subjective satisfactions for public order and supplies/services.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt that if the order of detention was based on the subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community, it would be bad because the incident of dacoity in a third class compartment of a running train set out in the grounds of detention would be wholly irrelevant to support such subjective satisfaction; it would be impossible for any rational human being to say that an incident of dacoity in a third class compartment of a running train where cash money was stolen is such an act that from it an inference can be raised that the person committing the dacoity would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be numberdoubt that if the order of detention was based on the subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely. to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, it would be bad because the incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train set out in the grounds of detention would be wholly irrelevant to support such subjective satisfaction. It would be impossible for any rational human being to say that an incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train where cash money was stolen is such an act that from it an inference can be raised that the person companymitting the dacoity would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services ,essential to the companymunity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solitary ground of train dacoity for cash theft wholly irrelevant to infer future prejudice to supplies/services; no rational nexus possible, applying unreasonableness test to subjective satisfaction.

holdings.text: The order of detention must be held to be invalid since the incident of dacoity in a third class compartment of a running train for committing theft of money which constituted the solitary ground of detention was wholly irrelevant and the subjective satisfaction of the District Magistrate that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community could not be founded upon it and was hence colourable and no satisfaction at all.

anchor.surface_text: And if that be so, the order of detention must be held to be invalid since the incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train for companymitting theft of money which companystituted the solitary ground of detention was wholly irrelevant and the subjective satisfaction of the District Magistrate that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity companyld number be founded upon it and was hence-colourable and numbersatisfaction at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Given dual basis of order including supplies/services satisfaction founded on irrelevant solitary dacoity ground lacking nexus, such satisfaction colourable rendering entire detention order invalid.

holdings.text: We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to invalidity of detention order due to colourable satisfaction on irrelevant grounds.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

outcome.relief_summary: Petition allowed; rule nisi made absolute; order of detention invalidated; petitioner directed to be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: We do number think we can accept this companytention of the respondent. It must be remembered that the affidavit-in-reply has been made by the District Magistrate himself and we must presume that the District Magistrate must have made the statements companytained in the affidavit-in- reply with the sense of responsibility which his high office necessarily carries. If the District Magistrate was also number subjectively satisfied in regard to the likelihood of the petitioner to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, he would number have made such an averment in paragraph of his affidavit-in-reply. Ordinarily when an averment is made by a high officer like the District Ma- gistrate in an affidavit which is made on oath, the Court is inclined to accept the averment as companyrect and the burden lies heavy on the party who alleges to the companytrary.
We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, accept the averment made by the District Magis- 7 L 319 Sup CIJ75 trate in paragraph 4 of his affidavit-in-ireply as companyrect and proceed on the basis that the order of detention was based number only on his subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order but also on his further subjective satisfaction that it was necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity.
We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.

anchor.surface_text: Now, there can be numberdoubt that if the order of detention was based on the subjective satisfaction that the petitioner would be likely. to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity, it would be bad because the incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train set out in the grounds of detention would be wholly irrelevant to support such subjective satisfaction. It would be impossible for any rational human being to say that an incident of dacoity in a third class companypartment of a running train where cash money was stolen is such an act that from it an inference can be raised that the person companymitting the dacoity would be likely to act in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services ,essential to the companymunity.
We, therefore, allow the petition and make the rule absolute and direct that the petitioner be set at liberty forthwith.
